Covid:
During the pandemic, Graham Health System has implemented and modified many policies, transitioning as our state moves to different phases of reopening. The efforts are continued, to this day.  

Staffing hours were abruptly reduced and employees furloughed, some positions terminated, organization wide as a result of declining volumes. There became a greater need for cross training as employees were requested to fill in for other areas.  As the Covid cases grew in our community, many of our staff were affected by IDPH recommended quarantine. It then became difficult to fully staff while our volumes were increasing.  The surge of patients and variable staff prompted the issuance of hazard pay to all employees for hours worked.  

Our physician clinics and convenient care were open less hours with one satellite clinic closed for several months.  Many services were ceased for a period of time, including: cardiac and pulmonary rehab, aquatic therapy, pulmonary function tests, and elective surgeries.  Community wellness and annual wellness outreach were postponed.  Most areas saw a reduction in volumes as patients delayed preventative health screens and elective procedures.  

There became a challenge to obtain some supplies as the organization ramped up the usage of PPE.  Many items that were reusable, became replaced with disposable supplies.  Once reliable vendors had difficulty supplying orders in a timely manner and/or increased prices to make up for the challenges they were experiencing in production and distribution.  The pharmacy had to adapt to medication shortages. Eventually, the rise in prices caused an inflationary period in all areas of non-salary expense. 

Several physical changes occurred to our facilities.  The Surgery endo suite was converted to a 5 bed Covid unit with negative air pressure rooms. ICU rooms were made into permanent ISO rooms as well as rooms in ED, PCU, OB and Med/Surg. A drive-through testing site was established in the physician clinic to keep suspected positive patients from entering public areas.  Fewer entrances into the hospital were allowed for visitors and staff in order to centralize symptom and temperature checks.  

The organization began to rely on technology even more.  Equipment and staff training were quickly needed to begin Telehealth visits.  Technology setup began in the new Covid unit and drive through lab site with already limited staff. Video conferencing was utilized for virtual meetings. Skype accounts were set up for patients in our Extended Care facility in order for them to stay in touch with loved ones while visiting was restricted.  

Reduced hours in EVS posed a problem as deep cleans were needed more frequently.  Our laundry service vendor ceased providing service as a precaution to their workers. A new vendor was quickly sought after with a significant increase in price due to the urgency. 

In 2021 and 2022, there became a challenge of filling open positions. The more expensive alternative of agency staffing became heavily relied on. Wage scale adjustments were determined to be necessary in order to stay competitive with other employers in the area and to reduce the compression of the wage table throughout the organization.  Recruitment tools such as a sign on bonus and referral bonus program were implemented as the need for critical positions grew. Wage scale adjustments continued in 2023 while agency staffing was reduced but not eliminated. A annual retention bonus was implemented.

Plan for Diversity Recruitment:
There are a number of strategies used to inform the various stakeholders of our intention to utilize certified Minority and Women owned firms on our projects:
-Presentations to the various advocacy groups for the purpose of informing their members of the upcoming project, including bid packages, liming for bid solicitations, specific project requirements and M/WBE contracting and workforce goals as applicable.
Presentations historically made to members of Black Contractors United, African American Contractors Association Hispanic American Construction Industry Association, Federation of Women Contractors, and other advocacy or contracting membership organization seeking information on an upcoming major project.

-Participation at all prebid activities where in salient project focused information is provided to potential bidders including
contracting utilization goals and workforce goals as applicable. Anticipated outcome - Complete competitive bid with M/WBE utilization provided on bid day.

-Minority and women owned firm participation applied to every project. These goals are stated in specific request for proposal documents so that potential bidders clearly understand our intention to award stated percentages of the project to diverse firms.

-Bidders list review prior to solicitation by construction management firm or general contractor to assure that the certified minority and woman owned firms are notified and solicitation for participation on the specific project.
-Implementing compliance processes throughout all phases of project to assure that minority and woman owned firms are actually participating on the project and are being paid consistent with prompt pay provisions in the contract.
Challenges to Diversity Recruitment: While we have managed to successfully mitigate most challenges encountered in the implementation of our diversity program we still have challenges identifying certified minority and women owned firms in particular trade areas specifically plumbing and mechanical (HVAC). Firms do exist in these service areas but they are low in number. The lack of availability compromises our ability to achieve maximum participation in this functional area. A strategy we are implementing started with an availability exercise wherein we sought to identify all certified firms in this geographic area working in the area of focus. We were hoping to identify emerging and/or newly certified firms that may not be on our bidders' list. We try to help emerging plumbing and mechanical firms with mentor/protege agreements with larger firms.
HSFRB Assistance: The IHFSRB can assist in our efforts by continuing to encourage others to develop and implement robust supplier/contractor utilization programs. By providing certified, diverse firms with the opportunity of a consistent flow of work that they have a real possibility of winning, these firms have the possibility of increasing their technical capacity and financial depth. These firms will become organizationally healthy and will be able to hire more workers and take on larger and more complex jobs. They will become better business partners for us all.

*Set achievable but realistic goals

*Make M/WBE utilization goals part of your contract with construction management firms and general contractors. Goal achievement contract language flows down to the agreements of the subtrades.
*Put prompt pay language in contracts to assure the M/WBE as well as all firms are paid in a timely manner after the prime contractor receives payment. Small firms cannot wait 45 to 60 days for payment.
*Look at your hospital's payment processes. How long does it take to pay suppliers, vendors, Contractors? Is there a payment bottleneck in your process that can be eliminated?

It may be a bit difficult initially to recruit diverse firms. Pick up the phone and call the firm. Ask them to look at the solicitation and bid your work. Sinai Chicago (Sinai Health System), including Mount Sinai Hospital, Holy Cross Hospital, and Schwab Rehabilitation Hospital, is one of the largest safety-net systems in Illinois.  Located in the west and south west sides of Chicago, Sinai serves the most vulnerable populations in very diverse communities.  These communities, largely made up of low-income households and people of color, are disproportionately impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic.  

A majority of the zip codes in the systemâ€™s primary service area have over 15,000 confirmed cases of COVID-19. In fact zip code 60629, where Holy Cross Hospital is located, continues to have the highest number of confirmed cases to date in Illinois.  This has had and continues to have significant impact on Mount Sinai Hospital, Holy Cross Hospital, and Schwab Rehabilitation Hospital, all parts of Sinai Chicago.
COVID-19 and each subsequent surge of the pandemic have had several implication on the health system. This continues to impact many areas of Sinai Chicagoâ€™s operations including the following: 1) emergency department volumes, 2) inpatient admissions, 3) ambulatory and ancillary volume, 4) financial health, as well as 5) staffing and 6) through put.

Across the health system, patient volumes have declined significantly due to the pandemic. This was seen immediately after the citywide shut down with ED visits dropping 30% from March 2020 to April 2020. In 2021, ED visits have rebounded to only 85% of pre-pandemic volume (2019).
Given that a majority of Sinai Chicagoâ€™s patients come through the ED, this led to a negative impact on inpatient admissions as well, declining nearly 20% from March 2020 to April 2020. Inpatient admissions in 2021 continue to be down 6% when compared to pre-pandemic volumes in 2019. 

One of the greatest impacts of COVID-19 continues to be seen in the staffing shortage leading to a negative impact on both financial health and throughput.  The shortage of both nursing and key ancillary staff has caused the system to bleed an additional and unbudgetted $3-5 million dollars a month in premium labor expenses.  In order to manage the staffing challenges, both ambulatory and ancillary services saw substantial declines in volumes due to reallocating staffing resources to more critical inpatient units, especially during the second COVID surge. Coupled with a non-compliant population challenged with the social determinants of health, Sinai Chicago has still yet to rebound back to pre-COVID state. 

Despite these challenges, Sinai Chicago continues to make great efforts to serve the community when and where they need it most.  The system has since expanded to provide COVID-19 vaccination clinics within the community, telemedicine options for patients to receive care outside of the walls of hospital and clinic sites of care, as well as other innovative ways to deliver care and increase care plan compliance to make sure people get the care they need.

Covid: The post-COVID era was established in 2023; people were either wanting to forget it ever happened or move on as quickly as possible. While we were thankful for the lessons learned and strength that prevailed during this time, we continue to see some of the same struggles and some new ones coming forward. Rural hospitals are markedly challenged as COVID not only promoted but enforced remote working environments. This new climate makes it particularly difficult for organizations in which human resources were already scarce. Not only nursing positions, but entry level positions are increasingly harder to fill, given the vast amount of remote working opportunities available. We have become very creative not only how we recruit colleagues but also shifted our perspective on retaining. Efforts are highly focused on colleague development and growth. Due to inflation and the overall shift in the market, we have seen large salary swings through travel agencies, bonuses, base pay, and more. This in conjunction with supply costs has led to a spike in expenses causing organizations to look at their resources differently and become better stewards to maintain stability for the future. While resources continue to remain a top priority for rural hospitals, we also saw colleague safety rise to the top. Throughout COVID there was much concern for healthcare workersâ€™ exposure and subsequent risk; however, while we see a steady decline in COVID numbers, healthcare remains amongst the top in dangerous careers due to the increase in workplace violence. As a shift in mental health diagnosis and treatment facilities continue to see an inverse relationship, hospitals are seeing progressively more violence coming through their doors. Programs to help keep staff safe during these times are not only a priority but necessary. Signs can be seen throughout our hospitals, establishing a zero-tolerance environment for violence. Staff is trained how to de-escalate situations and keep themselves safe. Security is heightened and metal detectors are now present in emergency rooms. While Culture of Safety continues to be a top priority, that culture has shifted, and we are shifting with it to keep our patients and staff as safe as possible. While COVID-19 may no longer be a hot topic amongst the public, healthcare facilities across the globe will continue to see its effects for many years to come.

Covid:
During 2023 we started to see some relief from the pandemic and health issues the virus created.  We experienced some lingering staffing issues due to employees leaving the healthcare field during the pandemic.  

Many of the societal challenges from 2020 started to decline in 2023. Sparta Community Hospital continued to maintain an active Incident Command Process throughout the pandemic, although the activities of the team have diminished due to a significant decrease in infections and an increase in mitigation strategies.  

Specific challenges are as follows and are likely similar to most healthcare organizations:

1. The Unknown
Early in the pandemic, information was seemingly changing by the hour. The Incident Command team continued to monitor and address recommendations regarding the pandemic and tried to keep staff and the public updated real-time and explained that operations had and will continue to change quickly as new information and best practice recommendations were released by IDPH and CDC. 

2. PPE
The PPE supply chain was stressed to the max worldwide, but it did improved significantly in 2023.  The Supply chain was replenished and SCH was able to keep the necessary supplies on hand. During periods of limited supplies, Sparta Community Hospital continued to approach the management of PPE supplies in a realistic and responsible manner. The organization's Materials Management department has maintained adequate PPE supplies for staff and continues to evaluate supply chain availability in the case of a surge. The organization continues to follow guidelines for the use of PPE supplies to protect staff and patients.

3. Staffing
Sparta Community Hospital experienced staffing shortages during the pandemic due to infected staff and staff who chose to leave healthcare during the pandemic. There were months where the organization had low number of employees who contracted COVID-19. However, during the Omicron surge, the organization did experience a significant increase in positive COVID-19 cases in staff. In an organization that was already operating at minimal staffing levels, this obviously created stress on the ability to staff some departments, particularly clinical departments such as nursing, laboratory, and diagnostic imaging.  The staffing issues have remedied and we are at full capacity. 

Another staffing challenge was the growth of the nursing agencies, and, therefore, the agencies recruiting registered nurses from Sparta Community Hospital. Fortunately, the organization has experienced a decline in this practice along with a return of agency nurses to acute care facilities.  We no longer have a need for temporary staffing in any of our departments

Further, healthcare fatigue has caused a decrease in individuals with desire to work on the front line of healthcare and has dramatically decreased the number of applicants for open positions in the organization. Sparta Community Hospital partnered with nursing and medical assistant programs to increase the opportunity to recruit potential candidates for such roles.

4. Financial (Volumes)
From spring to late summer of 2020, Sparta Community Hospital volumes were greatly impacted. By August to September of 2020, many departments in the organization had recovered to almost normal volume. Sparta Community Hospital has been able to maintain and strengthen volumes in many service lines impacted by the pandemic. 

5. COVID-19 Testing Supplies
A challenge that has continued since the beginning of the pandemic for Sparta Community Hospital is maintaining an adequate supply of COVID-19 testing supplies for the Laboratory and Emergency departments. 

6. COVID-19 Vaccine
While the COVID-19 vaccine was developed in record time, the distribution, supply, and plan to vaccinate the public has been challenging and frustrating at times. Sparta Community Hospital collaborated with other local hospitals, as well as the County Health Department, to promote and administer the COVID-19 vaccine to staff and the public.

A challenge that Sparta Community Hospital faced during the pandemic, is a low percentage of vaccinated individuals in the service area. 
An additional challenge that Sparta Community Hospital faced was monitoring staff vaccination status and abiding by the mandated testing guidelines concerning staff who are not vaccinated. The organization made all efforts throughout the pandemic to encourage staff to receive the COVID-19 vaccine.  Staff are still encouraged to receive the vaccine, however, SCH does not mandate staff to have the Covid-19 vaccine. 

7. COVID-19 Fatigue
Like many organizations across the nation, Sparta Community Hospital has truly dedicated staff, but COVID-19 did increase fatigue. The organization's staff and providers are ready to move forward and focus on other health issues rather than just the COVID-19 virus.  The medical staff does not agree that Covid-19 should be considered "just another flu"  and have concerned regarding how society will embrace this.

There is no doubt the COVID-19 pandemic created financial and operating challenges for hospitals across the country. These challenges have been particularly severe for rural hospitals that were already struggling with shrinking margins, declining volumes, workforce challenges and other barriers to providing care. That impact continued in FY2023 for many rural hospitals. However, because the OSF HealthCare hospitals with 100 beds or less are part of a 16-hospital health care system, during FY23 they continued to realize benefits traditionally have already had support as a critical care hospital. These benefits include supporting operations and services, supplies, leverage of staffing and navigation of the regulatory and financial challenges related to the pandemic. Further, some areas that the OSF critical care hospitals do not independently need to support include centralized services such as revenue cycle, accounts payable and receivable, supply chain, sterile processing, human resources and the contact center for ambulatory needs.

Because these OSF hospitals are connected to a larger system, they are able to scale their delivery system, adjust care models, share clinicians and leverage digital tools developed by the health care system to provide services such as virtual hospitalists and nurse triage, and ICU remote patient monitoring. In addition, some patient populations have access to remote patient monitoring and 24/7 access to a digital care team to help them manage chronic diseases such as diabetes, hypertension, heart failure, COPD and asthma. Further, support for pregnant and postpartum women in Illinois on Medicaid is also available.

One area that these hospitals do continue to struggle with, however, is vaccine hesitancy in their communities. This hesitancy is no longer just for COVID-19, but currently extends to the recent measles outbreak that has been reported in the state.

As a philanthropic pediatric specialty hospital, Shriners Hospitals for Children serves a vulnerable patient population, many of whom are unable to receive care elsewhere for a number of reasons including but not limited to the rarity and severity of their illness or disease, insurance coverage, and travel needs. While our patients' ability to receive treatment in 2023 improved over 2022, the pandemic continued to impact our patients and hospital operations moderately in 2023.

We were still using Agency/Travelers staffing at increased levels in 2023 but did see it decrease from 2022 totals especially in nursing. Planned Diversity Expenditures: Our organization seeks diverse suppliers for new construction projects, renovations, goods and services (where applicable) and some maintenance. We are a signatory of the Health Anchor Network which focuses on increasing the use of diverse suppliers. We are also members of Chicago United and active in the "Five Forward" program. Three of the suppliers we mentor (The Bowa Group Inc., Enviroplus, Inc, and Ujaama) we actively seek to both partner them with major contractors and on direct projects, to gain experience to take on larger, prime projects. It is an important part of our mission -To help people live well. By extending our business to diverse vendors, we build healthy and strong communities, economically.
Plan for Diversity Recruitment:
We have a number of strategies to continue to keep this top-of-mind with our core vendors and our construction leaders. They are as follows:

1. Minority and woman-owned (M/WBE) firm participation is included in every construction project that is put out for a bid
2. Advocate Health's goals and expectations are included in EVERY request for proposal (RFP) documents so that bidders are clear about our expectations
3. We make presentations for all AAH construction vendors every year. It is an expectation to attend. Senior leaders, as part of these presentations, present segments about our diversity and inclusion (D&I) expectations and goals

5. We make presentations to external groups on our supplier diversity objectives, goals, strategies and measures (OGSM) during the year. African American Contractors Assn., and Hispanic American Construction Industry Association are two groups we make presentations to.
6. Advocate Health has an experienced,  full-time system leader for this work, who works with senior construction leaders closely
7. In meetings with general contractors on projects, a discussion about and review of spending occurs at least quarterly
8. Construction Directors for Advocate Aurora Health have discussions about results on their projects in the 1:1 reviews
 with the System VP-Design & Construction quarterly
9. We exhibit and present at tradeshows and share current organizational needs

Covid: The post-COVID era was established in 2023; people were either wanting to forget it ever happened or move on as quickly as possible. While we were thankful for the lessons learned and strength that prevailed during this time, we continue to see some of the same struggles and some new ones coming forward. Rural hospitals are markedly challenged as COVID not only promoted but enforced remote working environments. This new climate makes it particularly difficult for organizations in which human resources were already scarce. Not only nursing positions, but entry level positions are increasingly harder to fill, given the vast amount of remote working opportunities available. We have become very creative not only how we recruit colleagues but also shifted our perspective on retaining. Efforts are highly focused on colleague development and growth. Due to inflation and the overall shift in the market, we have seen large salary swings through travel agencies, bonuses, base pay, and more. This in conjunction with supply costs has led to a spike in expenses causing organizations to look at their resources differently and become better stewards to maintain stability for the future. While resources continue to remain a top priority for rural hospitals, we also saw colleague safety rise to the top. Throughout COVID there was much concern for healthcare workers exposure and subsequent risk; however, while we see a steady decline in COVID numbers, healthcare remains amongst the top in dangerous careers due to the increase in workplace violence. As a shift in mental health diagnosis and treatment facilities continue to see an inverse relationship, hospitals are seeing progressively more violence coming through their doors. Programs to help keep staff safe during these times are not only a priority but necessary. Signs can be seen throughout our hospitals, establishing a zero-tolerance environment for violence. Staff is trained how to de-escalate situations and keep themselves safe. Security is heightened and metal detectors are now present in emergency rooms. While Culture of Safety continues to be a top priority, that culture has shifted, and we are shifting with it to keep our patients and staff as safe as possible. While COVID-19 may no longer be a hot topic amongst the public, healthcare facilities across the globe will continue to see its effects for many years to come.

Planned Diversity Expenditures: Our organization seeks diverse suppliers for new construction projects, renovations, goods and services (where applicable) and some maintenance. In many cases, these suppliers should have either healthcare experience and/or healthcare construction certification. In most cases, the suppliers will work as subs on projects. We are a signatory of the Health Anchor Network which focuses on increasing the use of diverse suppliers. We are also members of Chicago United and active in the "Five Forward" program. Three of the suppliers we mentor (The Bowa Group Inc., Enviroplus, Inc, and Ujaama) we actively seek to both partner them with major contractors and on direct projects, to gain experience to take on larger, prime projects. We have also recommended these suppliers to other health systems. Advocate Aurora Health actively seeks out design & construction suppliers, that are diverse, across both states we operate in. It is an important part of our mission -To help people live well. By extending our business to diverse vendors, we build healthy and strong communities, economically.
Plan for Diversity Recruitment:
We have a number of strategies to continue to keep this top-of-mind with our core vendors and our construction leaders. They are as follows:

1. Minority and woman-owned (M/WBE) firm participation is included in every construction project that is put out for a bid
2. Advocate Health's goals and expectations are included in EVERY request for proposal (RFP) documents so that bidders are clear about our expectations
3. We make presentations for all AAH construction vendors every year. It is an expectation to attend. Senior leaders, as part of these presentations, present segments about our diversity and inclusion (D&I) expectations and goals 
4. We ask for and expect reports quarterly from our major suppliers to insure goals are being met
5. We make presentations to external groups on our supplier diversity objectives, goals, strategies and measures (OGSM) during the year. African American Contractors Assn., and Hispanic American Construction Industry Association are two groups we make presentations to.
6. Advocate Health has an experienced,  full-time system leader for this work, who works with senior construction leaders closely
7. In meetings with general contractors on projects, a discussion about and review of spending occurs at least quarterly
8. Construction Directors for Advocate Aurora Health have discussions about results on their projects in the 1:1 reviews
 with the System VP-Design & Construction quarterly
9. We exhibit and present at tradeshows and share current organizational needs
Challenges to Diversity Recruitment: The challenges remain with needing more preparation to get suppliers prepared for larger and more difficult projects, especially a specialized area like healthcare. We continue to have difficulty in diverse utilization in our projects in more rural parts of the state. More development and utilization of diverse construction and design firms by other health systems, along with our efforts, will help to build a more robust group of capable suppliers for Illinois.

Encourage vendors that qualify to become certified through one of the recognized third-party certifying bodies to make their business more visible. Healthcare construction may require or constitute a different level of risk and/or additional training and awareness that other industries may require. Healthcare construction courses and entry level programs may also be marketed to open doors to new opportunities. Covid: The post-COVID era was established in 2023; people were either wanting to forget it ever happened or move on as quickly as possible. While we were thankful for the lessons learned and strength that prevailed during this time, we continue to see some of the same struggles and some new ones coming forward. Rural hospitals are markedly challenged as COVID not only promoted but enforced remote working environments. This new climate makes it particularly difficult for organizations in which human resources were already scarce. Not only nursing positions, but entry level positions are increasingly harder to fill, given the vast amount of remote working opportunities available. We have become very creative not only how we recruit colleagues but also shifted our perspective on retaining. Efforts are highly focused on colleague development and growth. Due to inflation and the overall shift in the market, we have seen large salary swings through travel agencies, bonuses, base pay, and more. This in conjunction with supply costs has led to a spike in expenses causing organizations to look at their resources differently and become better stewards to maintain stability for the future. While resources continue to remain a top priority for rural hospitals, we also saw colleague safety rise to the top. Throughout COVID there was much concern for healthcare workersâ€™ exposure and subsequent risk; however, while we see a steady decline in COVID numbers, healthcare remains amongst the top in dangerous careers due to the increase in workplace violence. As a shift in mental health diagnosis and treatment facilities continue to see an inverse relationship, hospitals are seeing progressively more violence coming through their doors. Programs to help keep staff safe during these times are not only a priority but necessary. Signs can be seen throughout our hospitals, establishing a zero-tolerance environment for violence. Staff is trained how to de-escalate situations and keep themselves safe. Security is heightened and metal detectors are now present in emergency rooms. While Culture of Safety continues to be a top priority, that culture has shifted, and we are shifting with it to keep our patients and staff as safe as possible. While COVID-19 may no longer be a hot topic amongst the public, healthcare facilities across the globe will continue to see its effects for many years to come.

Covid:
Covid-19 protocols have now been eased at our facility, but we do continue to keep masks readily available for any patient that comes in with any type of respiratory symptom...or for those who just merely want the added protection, for themselves.  We are no longer staffing or conducting any type of wellness check upon entry, nor are we maintaining any type of visitor restriction to those patients in our Acute Care wing.  The following excerpt is actually the response that we submitted in our last annual survey...but it does reiterate the struggles that we were facing, while in the midst of the pandemic crisis.  




"We have expended a tremendous amount of resources and manpower as part of the pandemic response efforts. For one year of COVID response efforts through March 2021, we estimated that we have spent at least $1 million in staff resources and expenses associated with response efforts. We received over $4 Million in CARES Act Stimulus funding. We did apply for and receive $2.4 million in SBA PPP loans that we anticipate being forgiven. However, guidance keeps changing and the SBA is backlogged on processing and auditing forgiveness applications. As such, there is still so much uncertainty and limitations on utilization of the COVID funding, that we are uncertain how much of the funds we will even be able to keep. 

We have had our incident command activated for over a year now since mid-March 2020. We were holding daily incident command meetings, then reduced that down to 3 days per week and we are currently now at 2 days per week. Staffing the temp check stations has been challenging. At the onset of the pandemic, we used staff temporarily displaced when their department services were shut down. However, once services resumed, it got more difficult to staff the temp check stations and in many cases, it has caused overtime. We are still staffing temp check stations for patients/visitors, incurring additional staffing costs associated with that (approximately $18,000 per month). Our employee entrances at first were staffed with individuals but we eventually switched to automated temp check stations that use facial recognition to read temps that employees then manually log on paper since we donâ€™t electronically archive any data captured on the tablets. It really doesnâ€™t seem logical to continue the temperature taking, since many COVID symptoms have not even included high temperature. We have not heard any IDPH or CDC guidance permitting the discontinuation of the temp check station requirements, which is only adding to the staff shortages and extra costs that could be avoided without an increased risk for exposure.

We have been able to maintain adequate levels of PPE and sanitation cleaners for staff utilization. Weâ€™ve just experienced inflationary costs and delivery delays. We have had some staff complain about having to work outside to collect COVID testing swabs in the ER entrance drive-up when it was cold or raining. We had delayed delivery of rain coats that were ordered for staff to utilize, that eventually did arrive. We also changed up the process to address their concerns regarding testing during inclement weather. There were some complaints regarding pressure sores due to extended use of N95 masks while working on the COVID isolation unit. We purchased CAPR hoods for use to address these concerns. Some staff have complained that we didnâ€™t pay COVID hazard pay or pay for picking up extra shifts. However, we already had policies in place to pay time and half for overtime and when staff were called in to cover shifts. We didnâ€™t have to designate a COVID unit on our inpatient floor until around January and we saw the height of our COVID treatment at the first of 2021 (as opposed to patient spikes in urban areas at that the start of the pandemic). We didnâ€™t give hazard pay for working those units because risk of COVID exposure was not limited to just nursing. Reception, housekeeping, ancillary staff, etc. were all at risk. Therefore, paying hazard pay only for specific staff members would not have been equitable.

Dealing with the COVID pandemic has definitely taken a toll on our staff and they are feeling stressed. In rural hospitals, we treated fewer COVID patients than urban areas; however, we didnâ€™t have excess manpower to adequately deal with all the added responsibilities of response efforts, including organizing, communication, developing new policies/processes, tracking new funding and expenses, staffing testing hotlines and specimen collections, administering vaccines, staffing temp stations, etc. This has meant overtime by a lot of staff that has continued for over a year now. It is also hard to find and keep workers because so many prefer to take the unemployment benefits when it is hard enough to find qualified individuals in rural areas. Every employee was impacted in some way or another by the pandemic. We therefore opted to treat all employees equally and did appreciation events routinely throughout the COVID response period. We had cookouts, used COVID grant funds for hospital logo appreciation items like coolers (Keeping Cool Under COVID), gift cards to local businesses (since they were hit hard by COVID and we had some staff with reduced hours during shutdown, the extra money assistance would help show appreciation and compensate for lost time and also those that worked â€œextraâ€), logo jackets (since we had to cancel our annual appreciation party). We also did an across-the-board market adjustment January 1, 2021. We couldnâ€™t claim that as COVID funds. However, we didnâ€™t have to give a market adjustment to all employees, just those positions that had to move because of the minimum wage increases. We just figured that helped address any wage compression issues as well as showed our appreciation to all staff for their COVID efforts. Weâ€™ve talked about giving COVID bonuses now since itâ€™s surpassed a year that weâ€™ve been dealing with this. However, we are concerned whether HHS will change the guidelines and disqualify a bonus paid out this late in the pandemic.

We did have to reduce a limited amount of work schedules between mid-March through around May 2020 when we could resume services that had to be discontinued during the shutdown. Some staff were relocated to other job functions like housekeeping and temp check stations. Other staff did begin working remotely, if permissible for their job function. Some staff continue to work remotely, if we cannot accommodate social distancing within their on-site workspace. Those with compromised immune systems were permitted to take time off from work while retaining their benefits. All employees were given up to 80 hours of COVID benefit time eligible for use, per defined qualifying factors and could utilize other available benefit time during these periods of time off.

Revenues have been definitely impacted, but weâ€™ve also added new services like aquatic therapy and expanded upon services like adding a full-time general surgeon in October 2020 which have increased revenues in certain areas. Because of the limitations placed on calculating lost revenues for retaining the COVID Stimulus funds, it will make it difficult to carve out these new/expanded services in order to have an accurate impact of what the pandemic did to our operations. As such, that means less COVID funds that we will be able to retain.

Patients have also struggled, given that weâ€™ve had to restrict visitors. Many patients require that family interaction, as well as assistance with understanding their healthcare issues and making decisions. While we did accommodate those situations as permitted within the restrictions, dealing with end-of-life care under such restricted visitation was extremely difficult. Family should have been able to see their loved ones in their final days and the COVID pandemic restrictions prevented that. This will undoubtedly leave lasting scars on many who had to deal with loss, during this time period."

Covid:
There is no doubt the COVID-19 pandemic created financial and operating challenges for hospitals across the country. These challenges have been particularly severe for rural hospitals that were already struggling with shrinking margins, declining volumes, workforce challenges and other barriers to providing care. That impact continued in FY2023 for many rural hospitals. However, because the OSF HealthCare hospitals with 100 beds or less are part of a 16-hospital health care system, during FY23 they continued to realize benefits traditionally have already had support as a critical care hospital. These benefits include supporting operations and services, supplies, leverage of staffing and navigation of the regulatory and financial challenges related to the pandemic. Further, some areas that the OSF critical care hospitals do not independently need to support include centralized services such as revenue cycle, accounts payable and receivable, supply chain, sterile processing, human resources and the contact center for ambulatory needs.

Because these OSF hospitals are connected to a larger system, they are able to scale their delivery system, adjust care models, share clinicians and leverage digital tools developed by the health care system to provide services such as virtual hospitalists and nurse triage, and ICU remote patient monitoring. In addition, some patient populations have access to remote patient monitoring and 24/7 access to a digital care team to help them manage chronic diseases such as diabetes, hypertension, heart failure, COPD and asthma. Further, support for pregnant and postpartum women in Illinois on Medicaid is also available.

One area that these hospitals do continue to struggle with, however, is vaccine hesitancy in their communities. This hesitancy is no longer just for COVID-19, but currently extends to the recent measles outbreak that has been reported in the state.

Covid:
Since COVID, we have seen a trend in patients and community members being selective with their time and resources. Past priorities and obligations  no longer carry the same weight, especially now that technical advancements allow people to connect with the outside world, without having to leave their home. 

In our community, it seems that people are protecting their time more and engaging in extracurriculars less. They are no longer interested in attending a support group when they can access Facebook support groups at all hours of the day or night, or in attending a health conference when a Youtube video provides all the same material in half the amount of time, or meeting in person when a virtual meeting can eliminate the travel time to and from. 

This even flows over to patients getting preventive health care. Patients were told for years to stay away, stay protected, stay safe. It was accepted to postpone non-urgent healthcare needs. Now, we see patients coming in with higher acuity conditions that should have been identified and/or monitored earlier through yearly wellness exams, screening mammograms/colonscopies, etc. This new cultural mindset minimizes the importance of preventive and population health. 

It is a much larger issue than we can change on our own. However, Red Bud applied for and received a grant from ICAHN that will be used to do community education and to raise awareness for outpatient preventive health.
